questions.question: Which of the following best defines relational algebra?
questions.option_a: A. A procedural query language used to define data structures
questions.option_b: B. A non-procedural language for describing data constraints
questions.option_c: C. A set of operations for manipulating relations in a database
questions.option_d: D. A language used for defining data models in ER diagrams
questions.explanation: Relational algebra defines a set of operations on relations to manipulate and retrieve data from relational databases.

questions.question: The project operator (π) in relational algebra is used to:
questions.option_a: A. Select specific rows based on a condition
questions.option_b: B. Select specific columns from a relation
questions.option_c: C. Rename a relation or its attributes
questions.option_d: D. Combine two relations based on a condition
questions.explanation: The project operator selects specific columns (attributes) from a relation, removing duplicates.

questions.question: In relational algebra, the select operator (σ) filters:
questions.option_a: A. Columns of a relation based on conditions
questions.option_b: B. Tuples of a relation based on conditions
questions.option_d: D. Relations based on schema structure
questions.explanation: The select operator (σ) chooses specific tuples (rows) from a relation that satisfy a given condition.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions make two relations union-compatible?
questions.option_a: A. They have the same number of tuples
questions.option_b: B. They have identical primary keys
questions.option_c: C. They have the same degree and attribute domains
questions.option_d: D. They have foreign key relationships
questions.explanation: Two relations are union-compatible if they have the same number of attributes (degree) and matching domains.

questions.question: The result of R ∪ S in relational algebra contains:
questions.option_a: A. Only tuples present in both R and S
questions.option_c: C. Tuples from R or S or both
questions.option_d: D. Tuples from R minus S
questions.explanation: Union returns all tuples that are in R, S, or both, removing duplicates.

questions.question: The intersection (R ∩ S) of two relations produces:
questions.option_a: A. Tuples that appear only in R
questions.option_b: B. Tuples that appear only in S
questions.option_c: C. Tuples common to both R and S
questions.option_d: D. All tuples from R and S combined
questions.explanation: Intersection returns only the tuples that are common to both relations.

questions.question: In the expression R – S, the result includes:
questions.option_a: A. All tuples in S not in R
questions.option_b: B. All tuples in both R and S
questions.option_c: C. Tuples in R but not in S
questions.option_d: D. Tuples common to R and S
questions.explanation: Set difference removes tuples of S from R, keeping only those unique to R.

questions.question: The Cartesian product operation (×) between two relations results in:
questions.option_a: A. A relation that includes only matching tuples
questions.option_b: B. A relation with all combinations of tuples from both relations
questions.option_c: C. A relation that joins attributes based on key values
questions.option_d: D. A relation containing distinct attributes only
questions.explanation: Cartesian product combines every tuple of one relation with every tuple of another.

questions.question: In an equi join, the comparison operator used is:
questions.explanation: Equi join uses the equality operator (=) to join two relations based on matching attribute values.

questions.question: Natural join differs from equi join because it:
questions.option_d: D. Does not require attribute name matching
questions.explanation: Natural join automatically removes duplicate columns with the same attribute name in the joined result.

questions.question: Which operator allows renaming of relations or attributes?
questions.explanation: The rename operator (ρ) assigns new names to relations or attributes for intermediate results.

questions.question: In relational algebra, duplicate rows are automatically eliminated in:
questions.explanation: Project removes duplicate rows by default when selecting columns.

questions.question: Left outer join ensures that:
questions.option_a: A. Only matching tuples are kept
questions.option_b: B. All tuples from the left relation appear in the result
questions.option_c: C. All tuples from the right relation appear in the result
questions.option_d: D. Only non-matching tuples are kept
questions.explanation: Left outer join keeps all tuples from the left relation and fills nulls for non-matching right tuples.

questions.question: Right outer join differs from left outer join because it:
questions.option_a: A. Keeps all tuples from the right relation
questions.explanation: Right outer join includes all tuples from the right relation and nulls for missing matches from the left.

questions.question: Full outer join combines the results of:
questions.option_b: B. Left and right outer join
questions.explanation: Full outer join includes all tuples from both relations, filling nulls where matches don’t exist.

questions.question: The symbol used for the project operation is:
questions.explanation: π (pi) is used to denote the project operator in relational algebra.

questions.question: Which of the following aggregate functions counts the number of tuples?
questions.explanation: COUNT is used to find the number of tuples satisfying a query.

questions.question: In the grouping operation, aggregate functions are applied:
questions.option_a: A. To the entire relation as a whole
questions.option_b: B. Independently to each group of tuples
questions.explanation: Grouping applies aggregate functions to subsets of tuples grouped by specified attributes.

questions.question: Which of the following expressions filters employees in department 5?
questions.explanation: σ Dno=5 (EMP) selects only those employees belonging to department 5.

questions.question: Given EMP(Name, Salary), π Name, Salary (EMP) will:
questions.option_a: A. Display all columns in EMP
questions.option_b: B. Display only the names and salaries
questions.option_c: C. Remove all rows from EMP
questions.explanation: Projecting Name and Salary shows only those columns from the EMP relation.

questions.question: Which of the following is true for equi join results?
questions.option_a: A. They exclude tuples without matching keys
questions.option_b: B. They may contain duplicate join attributes
questions.option_c: C. They always remove redundant columns
questions.option_d: D. They contain only primary key columns
questions.explanation: Equi join produces results where both join columns appear, potentially duplicating attribute data.

questions.question: Which operator is used to rename a relation as ‘Dep5_emp’ in σ Dno=5 (EMP)?
questions.explanation: ρ Dep5_emp(σ Dno=5 (EMP)) renames the intermediate result as ‘Dep5_emp’.

questions.question: Union operation requires two relations to have:
questions.option_c: C. Equal degree and compatible domains
questions.explanation: Union compatibility requires same degree and matching data types for corresponding attributes.

questions.question: Which operation returns unmatched tuples along with matched tuples?
questions.explanation: Outer joins include non-matching tuples, unlike inner joins that return only matches.

questions.question: The aggregate operator syntax  function list (R) represents:
questions.option_a: A. A join condition between R and another table
questions.option_c: C. An operation that summarizes data in R
questions.option_d: D. A rename operation for R
questions.explanation:  applies aggregate functions like SUM, COUNT, or AVERAGE to summarize relation data.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Cartesian product is true?
questions.option_a: A. It requires matching attribute names
questions.option_b: B. It combines all tuples from both relations
questions.option_c: C. It only returns matching tuples
questions.explanation: Cartesian product combines every tuple of one relation with every tuple of another.

questions.question: What will the result of EMP × DEPT contain if EMP has 3 tuples and DEPT has 2 tuples?
questions.explanation: Cartesian product multiplies tuple counts: 3 × 2 = 6.

questions.question: In outer joins, tuples with no matching values have:
questions.explanation: Outer joins assign NULLs to missing attribute values for non-matching tuples.

questions.question: Which join produces all possible combinations of tuples from two relations?
questions.explanation: Cartesian product generates all combinations regardless of attribute matching.

questions.question: In grouping, the clause 'Dno  Count ID, Average Salary (EMP)' means:
questions.option_a: A. Group employees by salary level
questions.option_b: B. Group employees by department number
questions.option_c: C. Aggregate data by job title
questions.explanation: This groups tuples by department number (Dno) and computes aggregates per department.

questions.question: Which relational algebra operation most closely resembles SQL’s SELECT clause?
questions.explanation: π corresponds to SQL’s SELECT clause, as it projects chosen columns.

questions.question: Which relational algebra operation corresponds to SQL’s WHERE clause?
questions.explanation: σ filters rows using conditions, similar to SQL’s WHERE clause.

questions.question: The result of R ∩ S will always be a subset of:
questions.option_d: D. Either R or S, depending on conditions
questions.explanation: Intersection returns tuples common to both relations, hence a subset of both.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly represents a rename operation?
questions.explanation: ρTemp assigns the name ‘Temp’ to the result of σ Dno=5 (EMP).

questions.question: The aggregate function AVERAGE in relational algebra is used to:
questions.option_b: B. Find the mean of attribute values
questions.option_d: D. Find the sum of attribute values
questions.explanation: AVERAGE calculates the mean of numeric attribute values.

questions.question: Which operator symbol is used for selection?
questions.explanation: σ (sigma) denotes selection in relational algebra.

questions.question: Which of the following operations may produce duplicate attribute names?
questions.explanation: Equi join retains both join attributes, possibly duplicating their names.

questions.question: Which join eliminates redundancy in join attributes automatically?
questions.explanation: Natural join removes one of the duplicate join columns, simplifying the result.

questions.question: Relational algebra serves as the theoretical foundation for:
questions.explanation: Relational algebra concepts form the theoretical basis for SQL operations.

questions.question: The output of the operation σ Salary>=40000 (EMP) will contain:
questions.option_d: D. All employees regardless of salary
questions.explanation: The selection condition filters all tuples where Salary is greater than or equal to 40000.
